Award.AwardTitle: Nanodroplets to nanoparticles: Integretated studies of freezing
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms program of the Division of Chemistry, supports the research of Prof. Barbara Wyslouzil and her students at The Ohio State University. The overarching goal of the proposed research is to explore the physics of freezing including the limits to which liquids can be supercooled, the transformation kinetics and the structure of the emerging solid phase. This research integrates experimental and molecular modeling. The specific experimental objectives include: 1) measurement of liquid-solid nucleation rates as nanodroplets freeze, 2) the exploration of the role of molecular structure on the relative importance of the surface versus bulk freezing and 3) the development to x-ray scattering techniques to follow the transformations in situ. Molecular modeling is used to understand the driving force for the surface freezing in chain-like molecules and to calculate liquid-solid nucleation rates to compare directly to the measured values. Freezing, or crystallization from the melt, is a fundamental physical process that plays a central role in a broad range of industrial and natural processes. Developing a deeper understanding of this phenomenon, measuring phase transition rates and exploring the role free surfaces play in freezing are all crucial for developing accurate models of industrial processes, atmospheric chemistry and global climate.

In a broader context, this work develops novel applications of small angle scattering, aerosol spectroscopy, and molecular modeling techniques that address fundamental problems in aerosol science. The results stemming from this work are of interest to researchers in nucleation, polymer physics, materials science, and aerosol and cloud physics. The program provides a rich and varied research environment for students, from high school to graduate level that is highly interdisciplinary.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Freezing is an important physical process that plays a critical role in industries as diverse as semiconductor processing, pharmaceutical production and purification, and metallurgy. In nature, freezing of cloud droplets affects both the cloud’s radiative properties and the chemistry that can take place. To develop accurate models of industrial processes, atmospheric chemistry and global climate it is important to be able to predict the conditions required to initiate freezing, the rate at which freezing occurs, and the role free surfaces play in freezing.

Intellectual Merit

The overarching goal of the research was to explore the physics of freezing including the limits to which liquids can be supercooled, the transformation kinetics and the structure of the emerging solid phase. The questions we addressed included (1) How do the degree of supercooling and the nucleation kinetics vary with sample volume and cooling rate? (2) How does molecular structure affect freezing? (3) Can we observe and characterize freezing on the surface of droplets as compared to bulk freezing? Our research efforts addressed these questions by employing a sophisticated set of experimental and data analysis techniques, and by conducting intensive molecular dynamics simulations.

 Experiments and theory focused primarily on the alkanes because these molecules are the building blocks of materials as diverse as lipids, surfactants, and polymers. Thus, understanding the behavior of the simpler, constituent molecules, including their ability to self-assemble and form layered structures, should enhance our ability to predict the behavior of the more complex molecules. We also conducted experiments with water because this molecule is in many ways the “opposite” of the oily alkanes. Our experiments with the relatively short chain alkanes – octane and nonane – showed that it was easy to supercool liquid nanodroplets far below the normal melting point. The freezing transition was easily observed by all of our analytical methods. In particular, pressure measurements could detect the heat released by the phase transition, small angle X-ray scattering could detect the decrease in particle size that arises because the solid is denser than the liquid, and infra-red spectroscopy could quantify the distribution of the molecues between the vapor, liquid and solid states. The kinetics of freezing suggested that for these alkanes freezing proceeded from the outside in, i.e. the surface organized first before the rest of the droplet froze. As illustrated in Figure 1, the molecular dynamics simulations are entirely consistent with this view. Furthermore, the simulations suggested that freezing can distort droplet shape from the spherical one generally assumed for small particles. In contrast, when water droplets froze, the kinetics were consistent with freezing starting randomly throughout the droplet. The water did not, however, freeze to the normal “hexagonal” form of ice. Rather it appeared to form a structure of interleaved hexagonal and cubic layers.

Broader Impact

Our work developed novel applications of small angle scattering, spectroscopy, and molecular modeling techniques that address fundamental problems in aerosol science. The approaches provide a new way to quantitatively investigate the freezing transitions with extremely clean samples under conditions that are far from equilibrium, and a powerful set of experimental tools that probe conditions very close to the still idealized requirements of simulations.
